framework_intro.para:
Here is a plan to help you write an abstract. Abstracts in medicine and health science have a combination of up to five moves. It is common in these disciplines to structure the abstract with headings such as 'Background', 'Methods', 'Results' and 'Conclusion'.
There are spaces for you to add the content of your abstract.

commentary.para: The abstract occurs at the beginning of your dissertation or thesis. The main aim of the abstract is to provide the reader with a summary of your research.
The abstract is usually written at the end of the research process, and after writing the rest of the dissertation.
The model extract is from an abstract in the field of medicine, from the ‘European Journal of Public Health’.
Abstracts in most disciplines have a combination of four moves. This extract has the four moves that most disciplines have and also includes a fifth: highlighting the implications of the research.
Here is the framework that was used to present this abstract.
The purpose of this move is to highlight the current state of knowledge in the field.
The purpose of this move is to summarize either the aims of the text (i.e. this paper, essay, thesis or dissertation) or the research process (the aims, methods, findings).
The purpose of this move is to recount the methodological steps in the research.
The purpose is to summarize the findings/results of the study.
The purpose of this move is to highlight important implications of the research.
It is common in the field of medicine to structure the abstract with headings.
Use of the present tense, the present perfect tense or the past tense for presenting background information and presenting aims.
Here, the past tense is used to summarize the aims of the research process.
Here, the present tense is used to provide background information.
Use of the passive voice when explaining the method.
Use of the present tense or the past tense when summarizing results. Here, the past tense is used.
Use of the modal verb ‘should’ when highlighting implications.

checklist.point: Decide on the key findings of your research.
Think about the number of moves you need for your discipline.
Decide on the most appropriate order of moves.
Make some notes and organize them into the plan.
Use academic language.
Avoid too many technical terms and lengthy references in the abstract.
Language Bank: highlighting implications
Grammar Focus: providing background information
Grammar Focus: presenting the aims
Grammar Focus: explaining the methods
Grammar Focus: summarizing the results
Have I presented the aims of the paper or research?
Have I provided sufficient background information?
Have I explained the methods used?
Have I summarized the results?
Have I highlighted the implications of the research, if appropriate?
Have I used only the key information from my research?
Have I avoided using too many technical terms and lengthy references?
Have I used tenses appropriately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Writing an Abstract 3: medicine
paragraph.desc: How to write an effective summary of your research

paragraph.name: Move 1: Providing background information
paragraph.desc: Highlight the current state of knowledge in the field.

content.para:
Background:
The Netherlands Nutrition Centre (NNC) recommendseating a daily breakfast, preferably including products from five food groups.

paragraph.name: Move 2: Presenting the aims
paragraph.desc: Summarize either the aims of the text (i.e. this paper, essay, thesis or dissertation) or the research process (the aims, methods, findings).

content.para: The aims of this study were to examineto what extent breakfast consumption …

paragraph.name: Move 3: Explaining the methods
paragraph.desc: Recount the methodological steps in your research.

content.para:
Methods:
A cross-sectional study was conducted…

paragraph.name: Move 4: Summarizing the results
paragraph.desc: Summarize the findings/results of the study.

content.para:
Results:
The percentage of participants who reported consuming breakfast every day variedbetween 62.9 and 95.5 in different subgroups …

paragraph.name: Move 5: Highlighting the implications
paragraph.desc: Highlight the most important implications of the research.

content.para:
Conclusion:
Health promotion efforts should aim tostimulate breakfast consumption …Future research should investigate…
(Adapted from Raaijmakers et al., 2010.) For the full reference, click Help and select References.
